description.text: The Lytro Camera is a 3D camera. As an experiment, I'm making 3D anaglyph photos using the Lytro. By cutting up a pair of red/cyan glasses, the gel filters slide easily into the holder. You can make your own filters or diffusers by trimming gel filters that you can get at most photography or art supply stores

Who doesn't love Ghibli Movies?  
Long story short: I needed a spicerack, and took the long way around instead of just buying one. And since i'm an animation freak... well.  
The spice rack accommodates 4 tall bottles on every level. For a total of 12. You can make it longer rather easily, or cut two without the extra silhouette facing and join them. Nail / Mounting holes included.   
Send pictures!
If you like the projects on my Thingiverse, consider giving a tip. Not only I will appreciate it immensely, I promise to put it to good use. Thanks for your consideration!

INSTRUCTIONS:
-USE 3 mm material (MDF or veneer) Cut everything. Assemble the central box and paste joints for extra strength. Attack the silhouetted faces with glue. Varnish or paint to your liking. NOTE: notches are included on every join to account for kerf, resulting in an assembly which can be done with mere pressure. Kerf of course, varies, so this may end up being too thick for some. If that happens, lightly sand joints.

• This Holder is not required Support at all. So very easy to clear up.
  • You can add you name and company eaily.
• Just print and there are using very little support at all.

description.text: Computer Wire Exits for use with 3/4" Plywood.

Bracket to hold a 30mm fan next to the extruder utilising some existing holes in the X axis carriage.
The hot end can be removed from the printer without disturbing the fan

Fan bracket laser cut from 3mm acrylic. The screws to attach the bracket had to be M3.5 as the existing holes were 3mm dia. I suppose some suitable self tappers would be OK. The small holes were tapped M3 to attach the fan with some spacers.
The metal hot end was fabricated using some 0.4mm ally sheet to make some washers (36mm dia) spaced with ordinary 6mm washers on a 6mm spindle as per pictures.
This works really well with the following figures.
heating block 220c, bottom fins 36c, top fins 21c. The fan was connected to the heater as this was the easiest set up I could think of. When the power is turned off the temp rises to a max of 47c which is OK.
This came about as the metal hot end bought through eBay was rubbish with only 7 cooling fins instead of the 10 illustrated in the listing :(

Want to add an Arduino or Raspberry Pi to your Create®, but your printer cannot fit the whole bin part in a single build? Here you can build a Create® bin bottom with mounting bosses to integrate your favorite microcontroller in two halves! This bin has hole patterns for Arduino Uno, Leonardo or Yun, and Raspberry Pi (Model A or B). See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:732759 for the bin model to designed for a RPi A+, B+ and RPi2. We also have one that includes a caster. Created for those printers that can only accommodate half of a Create® bin per job, these files are designed to fit easily together with just a dab of your favorite adhesive (or solvent)! Have a lot of weight on your robot and want to provide an even more stable platform for your Create®? Check out our bin variant that integrates a second caster! You can find extra casters here: http://store.irobot.com/caster-assembly-create-2/product.jsp?productId=55736906&cp=3335976&parentPage=family If you chose to modify your bin with one of these designs, don't forget to also print your bin latch so you can maintain all of the retaining features on Create® robot! What can you make possible with your Create®?

Find instructions here:
http://www.irobot.com/~/media/MainSite/PDFs/About/STEM/Create/Create_2_Bin_Modification.pdf

description.text: With the Airboard you could do a really fun car. Look this project on kickstarter: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/223628811/the-airboard-sketch-internet-of-things-fast/description

A hamiltonian path is a path that visits each vertex exactly once - in a dodecahedron, it can be done with a beautiful cycle.   
As an added math bonus, this figure can be composed from 32 equal cuboids with two 45 degree chamfers that create square cross-sections. For those interested: the radius of the circumscribed sphere in relation to each side of the square is about 3.1935.   
I think it should be able to print without support, but the support I printed came clean off. Also, there's only a very small contact point with the bed, so I sunk the model a few layers into the bed. The first two tries, the printer head tipped over the model, messing up the whole print.  
If you make one, please share the results!

comments.text: For those wondering: with its 24 vertices, this is a Hamiltonian cycle of the truncated octahedron graph.

title: NORTH COUNTRY SPECIALTIES Free DXF download 12 inch 3d printer the NCS P3Steel I3V
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
• PRUSA i3 Steel with 12"x12"x12" work area DXF Files included for it
  • Designed to use the common 10 Gauge steel found in the U.S.
  • Can be setup with either V slot or traditional round rod Guides
    handy for upgrade from smaller units
  • The correct mounting holes for the PSU 4mm mount four patterns
    1, First pattern for Chinese s-360- 12
    2, Second pattern Mean Well Power Supply RSP-500-12 recommended
    3, Third pattern for Mean well Power Supply RSP-750-12
    4, Fourth Pattern for Mean Well Power supply RSP-1000-12
  • Generic X plate included for V slot configuration
  • X plate motor mount and idler plate included v slot configuration
  • Top has additional mounting points for different accessories
  • Most other PRUSA i3 steel accessories interchange except Y idler prints
  • Downloadable free version is Based on my Prototype
  • It does not support full 12" X or Z travel with dual extruder
  • Should be able to achieve 12" on X and Z with single extruder depending on style.
  • Does not include spool mounts,
  • Does not have provisions for Y-axis lead screw capabilities
  • It is based on my prototype some tweaking may be required,
  • Cutting of V slot is necessary to fit
  • Download latest version for minor upgrades
  • Z rod brackets now match Paid version as does the bed and Y belt mount for stability.
  • able to accept metal Z and X brackets for round rod configurations http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1154729
  • DOWN LOAD THE LASTEST VERSION for the most up to date file
  • Very Little updates will be done to these Files for the Free Downloadable files
  • go to my purchased version if you want more refinement, more options and other cool updates http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1125537

• very little plastic used in this printer set up as a V Slot
  • most hardware purchased from open builds store
  • Cheap Chinese PSU NOT recommend, to much power draw with 12" bed
  • Recommend printing some upgraded parts once up and running
    1 Search for NCS Stuff for recommend parts
    2 Highly recommend Z Travel end stop
    3 Y Axis belt mount, metal one provided is intended for temporary use it sucks recommend printing NCS one as soon as possible
    4 Y Motor Spacer for single plate motor mount
    5 some feet http://www.thingiverse.com/search?q=592637
  • If built as V Slot version and using the micron extruder no printed parts needed to get up and running.
    1, Free version will need extruder mount of sorts to get up and running.
  • animated version of assembly of standard PRUSA i3 Steel some minor differences but should help https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=In_Q6NkX3fs

description.text:
This 3D-printable bowl is perfect for candy and other goodies. Use it to serve your guest on a movie night and also show off your favourite hobby and 3D-printing skills!  
We designed the bowl specifically for testing 3D-prints with large-bore nozzles. In this image we show the result of a 1.0 mm nozzle 3D-print at 0.8 mm layer height.  
Even though it is possible to print this bowl at higher speeds, we kept it down to achieve a high-gloss shiny surface. The bowl is 136 mm wide and 60 mm tall. At around 20-30 mm/s it took less than two hours to print.  
The bowl has a simple and decorative shape which makes it easy to print. To get rid of the layer-change zipper-line we used vase-mode in our print settings.  
To make the bowl strong and achieve optimal transparency we 3D-printed the candy bowl using taulman 3D t-glase (PETT) filament.

description.text:
This is a y-rod support re-mix of the Mendel y-rod support. These always seem to crack under a small amount of pressure and my existing ones had crumbled to the point that my y-rods weren't quite parallel anymore. Problem is the original support requires that you undo the whole printer arm to put the new supports on .... REMIX!   
My version just snaps right on and with careful use is just as good as the original with respect to holding the y-rod straight.   
I couldn't find the original Thingiverse file for the y-rod support so this model is modified from the Mendel plate found elsewhere on this website.

No instructions really, just remove the old supports with needle nose pliers and then snap these on. Helpful to do one at a time, that way one end of the y-rod is always supported.   
N.B - If you intend to replace all your y-rod supports then you will need to print 4 of these. Also I'm not guaranteeing that they will hold for the Z Rods or any of the other similar supports; just the y-rods.

Articulated modules for building modular robots. It is the repraped version of the Y1 modules that I have created for my PhD.
http://www.iearobotics.com/personal/juan/doctorado/Modulos-Y1/modulos-y1.html
Version 1.0 is the first one. It works and it is 3D printable, but the design should be improved in order to obtain a better printing quality. UPDATE: 09/Nov/2011
A new version has been released: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13442

For building the REPY-1 modules, two 3D objects should be printed: the body and the head. Also, a Futaba 3003 compatible servo is needed, along with six M3 8mm bolts, 5 nuts and 1 washer.
You can have a look at these pictures to see how to build it: http://fotos.iearobotics.com/index.php?album=modulos-repy-1 You can see one module in action in this youtube video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x7OYkaXNGrY I apologize for my bad English :-( In this video, you can see the minimal modular robot that can be built using two REPY1 modules: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QmFV8lIZhB8 Here is a very funny video showing the kind of modular robot that can be built if you print more modules. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GUuVUEFfbEg

comments.text: Yes, I did use the drawings of Steinblocke along with photos I found on the internet. The block is formed in ratios. For example the Height is equal to the Width, doesn't appear that way as the raised front portion gives the appearance of it being taller. When I discovered that, modeling the block was very easy. I'm surprised nobody has done it but can understand why with the ancient astronaut theories out there, Then your work being associated......  I was going to stop with the H block due to lack of photos of the other pieces but if you know where there is more reference materials I would be interested in completing the pieces in the Steinblocke drawing with your help. I would love to put these blocks out there and see how people build things with them. I was musing the idea if I ever completed the model set, of printing them out and donating them to gifted children classrooms, young minds not weighted down with our preconceptions.

No fooling! Volkswagen wasn't the first to squeeze the two banks of a V engine together to fit under one cylinder head, but they were the first to wonder what they would get if they put two of THOSE together with a common crank. The result was an engine with four banks of cylinders, which they called a "W" engine (a name that had already been taken by a 3-bank layout, Wikipedia argues the double-vee or WR might describe it better). VW tiptoed in, bringing W8 and W12 engines to market first, but I'm skipping ahead to the ultimate version, the W16. You might recognize this as the layout used by the Bugatti Veyron. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rDpSbhKXbOs W8/W12 versions now available for download! I will be adapting this new (crossplane!) crankshaft design to fit my VR engine models.

If you downloaded the W16 in the first few days and you're having trouble printing the crank, download the updated file, or the remixed one over there.-> Sorry!  
Pick an engine. Print one crankshaft and two sets of everything else, using a high infill setting (unless you're printing the W8, then you just need one crank, two block halves and one set of "W16" pistons and rods). Sand or hone the parts until the pistons slide easily in their bores, rods spin on their crank pins, and the crankshaft actually fits together. Use 3mm filament as wrist pins for the pistons and rods. Slide one pair of piston/rod assemblies onto each crank pin (note that the pistons are not symmetrical, the lower edges of the piston crowns should face the center of the block. Each pair of piston sharing a crank pin should be facing the same way, if that makes sense.), then assemble the crankshaft minus the end pins. It's a pain, but I've added reference photos. Glue if necessary. Slide the pistons into each half of the block, then line up the crank holes. Press one of those end pins into the hand crank, then use pliers to press them into the ends of the crankshaft.

A puzzle made of Elements of the Periodic Table (PSE). As the Order Numbers are engraved, it is very easy to solve ;) The intention was to have a PSE which could be combined in different ways. You can also form words with the symbol names.

Well you will need perl to generate the new files. Here is how to do so. If you have no perl or don't want to run the scripts, just use "pse_generated.svg" for having a set of all elements. 1.
Download and store the following files in the same directory: "element_var.svg", "periodic.csv", "generate.pl", "concat.pl".
Create a subdirectory called "data" 2.
Change "element_var.svg" to your needs like the colors, shape, size or position of the names.
The variable names starting with $ will be replaced by the values "periodic.csv". So you can even change all names and values. $o = order number
$u = mass
$n = name
$s = symbol
$v = (optional) 3.
After this setting, you run "perl generate.pl" to generate one SVG for each entry in your periodic.csv. The generated elements are stored in the subdirectory "data".
  • (optional)
    Run "perl concat.pl" if you want a single SVG containing all generated elements. The name of the all-in-one-file is: pse_generated.svg
    • Hints:
    It depends on your laser cutter settings if the puzzle parts snap to each other. If it does not, just scale the SVG bigger.

title: RaspberryPi 2 and B+ Case with magnets

description.text:
My new version of the RaspberryPi Case with magnets. This is an improved design from my A+ case http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:580757
The RPi is held in with 2.5mm screws in the bottom shell. The screws are directly bolted into the plastic. I usually make sure that the holes fit the thread by drilling it with a 2.2 mm drill.
The top attaches to the bottom by 4 magnets. With that I am able to achieve that there is not a single screw, fastener, etc. on the outside of the case. The magnets are 4mm in diameter and 4mm in height. I purchased mine from supermagnete.de with part number S-04-04-N

description.text: Simple an adaptor for accumulator.

My 3D CAD and additive manufacturing experimentation at Texas State led to this cool gadget!   
If stuck on a lightweight dowel, can you make it fly?  
its a 3 inch outer diameter  
The holes are for 1/16 inch screws, 3 or 4 self tapping ones should do the trick!  
I don't know much about fluid dynamics, but the sweep angle looks right. I'm printing one soon - if you beat me to the punch let me know how it works!

Make sure it is laying flat on the side without the holes.  
I have it scaled to print at 76.2 mm (3 inches) in the X or Y direction (uniform scaling ON), but feel free to blow it up! The wall thickness may become an issue if too much smaller.   
STL file was saved with max chord length of 1 and max angle of .25.

title: Y axis belt clamp with integral tightener

description.text: This is a simple replacement for the 18mm spacing belt that holds down the Y axis belt in my prusa.  This one has an integral belt tightener so you can actually adjust the belt tension after the thing is assembled.

The spacing is set up for my Makerfarm MDF bed (18mm center to center) but should work for others that use the same spacing.  I printed a pair, replacing both belt clamps with them.  The belt goes under the cutout, and just bridges over the top.  On my build, this seems to work great, and fixes two birds with one stone -- Keeping the belt clamps from working loose as they break, and giving me a simple way to adjust the y axis tension.
On the one toward the front, I installed a 3mm x 25mm screw and nut to work a ram I found elsewhere here.  That lets me extend the bed all the way forward and get to the screw from the front and tighten the belt between prints if needed.

title: ODROID C1 breakout frame for MLAB

description.text: 3D Printable Breakout frame which mechanically adopts the ODROID-C1 to MLAB (http://wiki.mlab.cz/) electronic prototyping and development system. The design even provides great increase of mechanical durability of weak ODROID's PCB board. The breakout frame accepts standard M3x12mm screws and nuts which are used normally in MLAB system.

The breakout frame is designed to be easily printable on almost all 3D FDM printers, it can be printed from ABS or PLA plastic with superb results. But an inspection of trace placement in thin walls is required after slicing.  
The model has bottom holes for nuts covered by one layer of material. This technological material allows slicing software to plan a bridge over all holes.  The bridge layer must be drilled of after printing by a 3mm drill.  
Hexagonal nuts should be inserted from bottom side to the prepared holes. M3x12mm screws for mount mounting ODROID board should be screwed from the top side.  
Other file formats and thing up to date source codes are freely available from MLAB's SVN Repository.

This is my take on an x-rod mount, inspired by the Prusa Mendel. It presses a screw directly against the rod to clamp it in place, and is extremely low-profile. I had trouble printing twotimes' version (the y-axis kept skipping when transitioning from the base to the clamp), so I built the clamp into the base.

Press the captive nut into the slot above the rod hole (tighten it onto a screw to press-fit it and make sure it's aligned), then insert the rod. Mount the clamp to the inside of the Cupcake body with four screws, then tighten down the clamping screw to lock the rod in place. You'll probably need a ball-end hex driver for this (my Makerbot came with one).

title: ODROID U3 breakout frame for MLAB

description.text:
3D Printable Breakout frame which mechanically adopts the ODROID-U3 to MLAB (http://wiki.mlab.cz/) electronic prototyping and development system. The design even provides great increase of mechanical durability of weak ODROID's PCB board.
The frame expect use of a PCB which has connectors for ODROID's IO port. Source files for this board are available in MLAB SVN repository. Spacing between screw holes is in MLAB's standard grid of 400mils (10.16mm).
The breakout frame accepts standard M3x12mm screws and nuts which are used normally in MLAB system.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

The breakout frame is designed to be easily printable on almost all 3D FDM printers, it can be printed from ABS or PLA plastic with superb results. But an inspection of trace placement in thin walls is required after slicing.  
The model has bottom holes for nuts covered by one layer of material. This technological material allows slicing software to plan a bridge over all holes. The bridge layer must be drilled of after printing by a 3mm drill.  
Hexagonal nuts should be inserted from bottom side to the prepared holes. M3x12mm screws for mount mounting ODROID board should be screwed from the top side.  
Other file formats and thing up to date source codes are freely available from MLAB's SVN Repository.

This simple chainmail is intended to be as quick and easy to print as possible, hence the square links and straight bridges. The one pictured here is striped because it was ditto-printed (an option in the Sailfish firmware to print simultaneously with both nozzles). This single print filled the whole Replicator build platform, but took just over an hour. 
This chainmail is extensible because the links along two edges are open, which allows you to knit other pieces of chainmail onto them them. You can see in one photo where I turned the sheet into a tube this way.

The included STL is meant to be ditto-printed, hence the three separate sets of chainmail 33mm apart. If you're not set up for ditto printing, you can output a continuous piece in Customizer, or adjust for different nozzle spacing. You can change other parameters as well, but if you make the thickness too large, you'll just end up with a solid plate. 
I sliced this with the MakerWare medium default settings with two changes: 3 shells and 0.25mm layers. This ensures it doesn't try to infill where there's not enough space and also makes sure you end up with the right number of layers everywhere. I used PLA with a big fan, printing on cold blue tape over kapton. Make sure your platform is extremely level and your first layer is just squished enough. This printed without a single link failing.

author: Dashlight

title: X Skis, X carriage replacement option for all Mendels

description.text:
UPDATED. An option to replace the X carriage on Mendel RepRaps. Variable length between bars.
Variable width for extruder mount, or other tools.
No more need for fitting things in the X carriage holes.
NO GLUE, but you can use glue instead of set screws if you like.
Hole for an LED to point down towards your print, and a channel to run the wire.
Less Plastic than anything I've seen so far.
*More visibility where the extrder filament drive meets the hot end. Pictures show the finished replacement installed and lit up. I have it connected to the blue toggle switch. Also show the intermediary step of changing it out.

for a full carriage replacement, print 4 bushings and the bridges file.
there are spots for M3 nuts to use with set screws to hold the bushings in place, OR glue them in.
you can optionally put a downward facing LED through the bridge, there is just enough room between the ends of the bushing extensions.
I think the easiest way to change this out on a Prusa Mendel is to loosen the screws holding the bars in place, pull them out towards the pulley side and slide the old carriage off and the new one on.
After tightening the belt I ended up putting a doubled up rubber band over the belt clamps and across the gap of the 2 skis... this maintains the pressure on the belt instead of letting the skis be separated by the tension.
Mount your extruder / tool.

title: TBS Discovery (Team BlackSheep) Brushless Gimbal / upgrade to Discovery Pro

description.text:
Finally my new design of the gimbal is finished and ready to get printed.
I have two desigs of the same gimbal as this one offers the backside vibration dampening inside the frame. It depends on how you'll use it and with which components togetther. Video filmed with this gimbal: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kbMH2tig0nU I added my own GoPro mount to the design. It offers the possibility to mount the GoPro upside down if you want and has two openings to access the buttons. Further this mount is capable of useing wiht the original 30-pin FPV out both upside down and normal. Note that it is still possible to use the normal USB FPV out if you like... I have a scond design which moves the backside dampening outside the frame and offers more space inside for electronics...
However, this design is the closest related to the original TBS Discovery Pro gimbal and should offer the best performance. Please notice, that this is the first version and minor changes could come Actually I noticed, that the longer pitch_mount is better suited for every GoPro, so keep this in mind when choosing the right mount for your purpose
Have fun!

Material needed:
1x Main plate
1x Roll mount
1x Pitch mount
1x GoPro mount (e.g. the one from Nathan_)
4x Vibration damper
2x 2208 Gimbal BL Motors
1x BGC (simpleBGC from BaseCam or any other)
and the TBS Discovery :)

comments.text: I deleted my previous comment because I was in error.  But, to help those out there that initially see massive shaking, the problem is not the gimbal, it is the Naza M PID's are too high and reacting fast enough to set up a resonance and massive shaking.  I fixed my shaking problem (thanks to adi380) by turning down my gains on the NazaM to the point that the unpowered Gimbal is steady.  Of course I lost a little of the rock steady response of the Naza by turning down the gains but now I do not have any shaking and the video is 95% more smooth.  I'll have to do some tweaking with the dampers to find a perfect balance between Naza M gains and damper stiffness to get the proper balance.  FWIW, I turned my Basic Pitch/Roll down from 170% to 135% and that fixed most of the problems....  Thanks again adi380
comments.author: thekubiaks

comments.author: Lioon

comments.text:
It is possible that as the shaft of the T-motors is longer than the one of my motors, that the shaft would touch the main plate and disable thus the dampening function by transmitting vibration.
The problem with the pitch mount could be true. This gimbal is designed for the smaller form factor GoPros as 3/3+/4 not 2. If you want to use it, that just print my main plate and roll mount and use a different pitch and camera mount.
The only 'negative' effect of the lens not being in line with the axis is, that when the gimbal turns the image could move a little bit up and down. But this would be only noticeable if you would film close to the ground, like filming flowers from very close. In the air this effect it's not noticeable at all because any point of reference is to far away. But it's pretty hard to design a gimbal for the GoPro to line up the lens with the axis.
The only way I can explain this jello is because you did not balance your gimbal. A good gimbal can only work if every axis is balanced perfectly. This is why most designs offer the possibility to move the arms to optimize the center of gravity to fit the intersection of the axis. So if you use a different camera with different C.G. it might not work anymore with the same gimbal as the holes in the mounts aren't placed good enough. Just keep in mind, that a well balanced gimbal should remain in any position you turn its without being turned on. If this is so, than every axis its balanced fine and the gimbal won't produce jello when operating.
comments.author: Lioon

But you can use the T-Motors as well, as they have the same mounting dimensions. You won't have to redesign anything as I made holes for the shaft. I am not sure if the space between the main plate and the roll mounting is big enough...

description.text:
Basic small 3D printable MLAB baseboard. The main advantage of this type of the base board is its availability over classical metal variants.  But metal variants have much better electrical and mechanical properties.   
The base board accepts standard M3x12mm screws which are normally used in  MLAB system.  
Other file formats and up to date sources are freely available from MLAB's SVN Repository.

The mounting board should be printed from ABS plastic for its flexibility.
It does not need a brim. The board should be printed with 100% infill.
It can be used immediately, does not need any mechanical working after proper print.

title: Glass bed magnetic hold down brackets.

description.text: Magnetic hold down brakets for Glass bed mod on Solidoodle 3.

Add the glass bed mod to your Solidoodle 3 without binder clips.  Print 1 Front Bracket and 2 Rear brackets.  Screw them to your Z-axis bed frame.  Then place and glue 4 magets to your glass while attached to the machine, I suggest using blue painters tape to catch any drips or overflow of JBWeld.  Then your glass beds will become super fast to change out. 
Caution hot glass may need oven mitts to move them.

title: Retro Pie Box Version 2 - Portable Raspberry Pi Emulation Console (RETIRED)

description.text: THIS PROJECT HAS BEEN RETIRED. I don't have a wiring guide or any additional information after what I've posted below. Thanks for the interest, but I'm hard at work on Version 3! This is an update to my previous Retro Pie Box. Here's video of it in action! - http://youtu.be/viSYd8yeHJs I've thrown in the new Raspberry Pi B 2 for good measure, simplified the entire design and created enough room in half the case to carry controllers, a mini keyboard, or a spare phone battery charger for additional play time. If HDMI is plugged in, it will default to it, if not, the screen will turn on. The main differences The lid of the left side now holds the RPi, and has the USB/Ethernet available through the open side. Power is now provided by a single 3.7v 6600mAh lipo battery instead of the complicated two battery system I had before. (This might need to be doubled up because of the power draw of the screen. Charging is done through an Adafruit PowerBoost 500+ http://www.adafruit.com/product/1944 There is a power switch that goes white when on, and a reset switch that is green when USB power is provided and thus charging the battery/powering the system. Last but not least is a funny problem. Now that the bottom is relatively empty, it tends to fall backwards due to the weight of the screen. I'm going to have to add a counterweight at some point soon.

Parts List Pelican 1200 Case - http://www.amazon.com/Pelican-1200-Case-Camera-Black/dp/B0002INQT2
7" TFT LCD Monitor - http://www.amazon.com/RearView-Headrest-Monitor-Support-Rotating/dp/B007SLDF7O/ref=sr_1_1?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1424300291&sr=1-1&keywords=7+inch+tft+lcd
Raspberry Pi Model B 2 - http://www.adafruit.com/product/2358
PowerBoost 500 - http://www.adafruit.com/product/1944
Lithium Ion Battery 6600mAh - http://www.adafruit.com/product/353
Panel Mount HDMI Cable - http://www.adafruit.com/products/978
Metal on/off switch with LED Ring - http://www.adafruit.com/products/917
16mm Momentary Pushbutton - http://www.adafruit.com/products/1440
2 x DIY Micro B Plugs - http://www.adafruit.com/products/1826
USB DIY MicroB Female Plug - http://www.adafruit.com/products/1829

description.text: Marble rolling toy

Put a marble in the starting location shown in the first photo, and try to roll the marble into the hole at the top without allowing the marble to fall into the larger pits. You can either hold it with your bare hands, or you can place it on a ping pong paddle. This design has several improvements over Marble Challenger 1, including: -a base to keep marbles from falling through the bottom of the toy
-a rim around the top edge to keep marbles from falling from the edge of the toy
-a larger finishing hole to better accomodate marbles
-a reasonable difficulty level (I couldn't finish Marble Challenger 1 after about 300 tries, but I finished Marble Challenger 2 after 10 tries)

An elevation map of The Netherlands! Get a new perspective on this beautiful country. Also check out the flooded version: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:699728 It has been simplified into 7 height levels using SolidWorks and Illustrator:
  • Level 1 is 12m below sea level
  • Level 3-4 is approximately at sea level
  • Level 7 is 14m to 300m above sea level
    • I did not print the height in the right scale; the country is so flat, that on scale, the total height difference would only be 0.2mm. I would recommend to scale x/y and z independently when fitting this to your printer bed. For more interesting calculations, check the comment section. If you make one, please share your result!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4mm nozzle, 0,1mm layer height

Infill:

30%

Notes: Pay attention to the retraction and travel settings of your printer (if your slicer allows you to modify it). Because of the quirky paths it has to make, the printer might make a hairy print and you'll spend 20 minutes removing those.

As a source, I used a Rijkswaterstaat topographic map. This is a map without any writing or drawing on it; it just shows the height of the area relative to sea level by using different colours. There might be programs that will automatically turn this into a gradual 3d-model, but I wanted to do it in a specific way. In Adobe Illustrator, I removed any noise from the picture and reduced the amount of colours to 7, which means it now has 7 different height levels. Then, I could isolate each colour, and put them in different layers. Each layer could be imported into a CAD program (in my case, SolidWorks), and be extruded to a height that made sense for my model.

I tried switching filament after the first layers to get a different colour 'neutral layer', but misunderstood the setting, so it did another white layer after the filament switch... The result however is better than I imagined. The unscaled Z-height of the 'neutral layer' is 1mm.  
For my Ultimaker Original, I scaled the X and Y to 0.25. The Z was scaled to 0.5. With 40% infill, the model took 7.15m of filament (53 grams).

Overview & background We don't see a lot of the world around us. There are mountains, lakes, oceans, but as a normal person you will never have the chance to view them from above and analyse it. Studying topography can learn you about an area's origin, its existence, the local struggles and advantages of nature, and an explanation of its wonders. This project is based on a model of The Netherlands and shows its struggles with the North Sea, but the idea can be extrapolated to other geographic areas - all you need is a topographic map. You might find one at https://www.arcgis.com/home/webmap/viewer.html, http://www2.jpl.nasa.gov/srtm/cbanddataproducts.html, or at a local website. Objectives By studying the model, students can get a better understanding of The Netherlands, but also on a greater scale, the world. Depending on age and level, they can do different analyses and calculations; for everyone, there are valuable lessons to learn. Audiences You can use this model in just about every age and skill level; from primary school to university, you'll find interesting subjects to talk about and different degrees of skill and depth. Subjects Geography, and to a lesser degree, Mathematics and History Lesson/Activity Since there are many options, I'll just bulletlist a few in short descriptions, chronographically from primary school upwards. Some of the questions here I've already answered in the explanation and the comments, but don't let that stop you from figuring them out again with your students.
  • Explore the country: where do you live? How big is the country? Why is it shaped like this? Where have you been in your life?
  • What would happen if the dikes break, and the seas or the rivers flow inland? (see also my remixed model) Simulate this by pouring water into the model, and see what happens. Push a pin into the model at different interesting locations: what happens to your own city? What happens to Amsterdam? What happens to the Wadden islands and Zeeland? Where would we go when this happens?
  • Discuss the simplifications in the model. Why is the Afsluitdijk not visible? Why is the highest point not jumping out? How realistic is this model, what can we learn from it, and what should we NOT learn from it? Why is it flat while the real country is part of a sphere?
  • Scale up: do calculations from this model. How would this look like on a sphere (earth)? How big would the sphere be? How mucht height difference would there be in the middle if it was on a sphere? How much is that in the real world - i.e. how curvy is the country? Get a better understanding of the scale of the earth. You might even introduce a ball the size of the moon in the same scale.
  • Use this model as inspiration, and let the students make their own model of The Netherlands. This one uses height, but there are many more ways to categorize a country. Draw, lasercut, paint, build, cut, sculpt your own version of the country; map forests, population, crime, rivers, traffic, or whatever you want. Imagine how the country would look like if it was in the tropics or the pole regions.
  • Create your own model of another country or region. Instructions can be found above.
    • The current model is actually being used in topography classes, as I've made several for a geography teacher that uses it regularly with her high school students. Preparation Greatly depending on the group you're introducing this model to. I'd like to think you can just plunge into discussion and assignments, but if you are not familiar with the country itself and its origins (the Dutch constant battle with the sea for instance), that might need some studying first. It's a very interesting topic anyhow, that any geography teacher would be enthusiastic to tell about. Results This depends too much on what you do with the model. You can use it for one lesson, but you might also build an assignment around it. Anyhow, I'd like to hear what you did, what the results were, and how you liked it! Show it in a Make.

comments.text: What would be the curvature on this model if you would want to map it on a globe?
comments.author: Barleon

comments.text: The curvature of every country would be roughly the same, since it has the radius of the earth; about 6,372 km. The Netherlands is about 310km at its widest, north to south from Rottumerplaat to Vaals. The calculations here are simple Pythagoras, although hard to explain in text; but according to my quick & dirty maths, this means that when you isolate the Netherlands from a globe and put it on a flat surface, it would be about 2km higher in the middle.
comments.author: Barleon

comments.text: That's exactly what I was wondering, thanks!
comments.author: mitrasmit

comments.text: Exactly - the country is much too small compared to the entire earth. And even England or France would only get an elevation of 3 to 4mm. For real results, take a stretched country like Chile (18mm), or just a vast one like Russia (16mm).
comments.author: Barleon

works in progress... Things for ZMR 250, ideas borrowed from others, but all "drawings" my own thanks to calipers.....  
The Arm spacers + stock arms brings a total of 12mm clearance between mid and bottom plate, the XT60 holder bit fit perfectly inside this 12mm space, and have a locking bit that holds the XT60 connector very snuggly.  
The "Lid" was me just goofing around, my daughter likes it... if you go without the top deck, and an naze mini you might actually be able to use it.....  hole drilling required... or something sticky.... or...  
More bits coming.....  
Added the traditional LED holder, 12mm so it completes the set.  I also just added some power distribution boxes, the one with "top" works for both, one is for a banggood 12v/5v bec power distrubtion, you can melt the single pin down to hold the board in... the other one has standard 30mm spaced pins, you can melt them down to hold the board down too....
